comments: you learn as much as you want to
If you're into the material and motivating yourself to learn without problem sets, then the material is very good and interesting.
Make sure you have the background necessary to take and understand the course.
A tutorial is great to take but it all depends on the teacher.
Take this class if you are interested in the topic and only if you have the pre-requisites, or else it will not be worth it.
Tutorials are a great way to have a more leisurely, but nonetheless closer look at a single topic within a field.

Taking a tutorial is a great way to really absorb yourself in one area of mathematics.  It was easier, but that allowed me to sink more time into really trying to learn the math.  Thanks to that and Jessica's comments, I feel like I came out a much better student of mathematics.

If you like the topic, take the tutorial! Even if you don't have the background necessary, if you're willing to put in some additional time, you'll probably be able to keep up with the course, and it can be a great source of ideas for independent study and theses.
These tutorials are a great way to get to look at some interesting material that you don't necessarily get to see in the mainstream math courses.
Matveev is a god.
Class can go fast at times! So be prepared to pay serious attention (don't let the low amount of work make it so you stop paying attention!)
Take it very seriously. If you don't you won't learn much, and that's both not good and not a good feeling.
99r is different with each set of lecturers, but in general I think the tutorials are good if you find the material to be of interest.
Tom is a great lecturer, and cyclotomic fields are a fruitful topic.  This will also likely be one of the smallest classes you take in the math department, which is a major plus.

It's a great chance to learn some math that is closer to research level math than what are in the typical undergraduate courses. It's also great to have a grad student as a professor. The small size allows the course to be fit well to the students taking it.
The tutorials are a great way to see high-level stuff in a low stress environment. If there's one about a topic you're into, definitely take it.
This was a great class: Danny is an excellent teacher.
Take your tutorial with Danny.
We ended up covering Tom Leinster's "Basic Category Theory" from the beginning to the end (examples were selected/reduced). I liked the increased individual attention due to the small class size (8).
Tutorial is a great way to learn something in Math. The class is small and the tutorial leader is easily approachable, so you can learn comfortably at a nice pace.

Morse theory tutorial with Boyu was a great class. Morse theory is a really cool topic in differential topology that gets passed over in the standard courses. The ideas all have intuitive pictures behind them and made me realize why many of the big theorems in math 132 are useful. Boyu's lecture were very clear and concise.
Have to be motivated to learn stuff outside of class.
Math 99r was a fantastic experience!  The small class size made it conducive to learning, and was is a great opportunity to learn about modern areas of research.  Konstantin was a fantastic teacher!
The tutorials are a good way to learn an interesting topic in depth. Very casual, laid back format. Not too much work but you still learn a lot.

Tutorials really depend on the people who teach them. Luckily, Konstantin Matveev was a great tutorial professor who covered interesting topics and taught the tutorial well while providing ample opportunities for student engagement. Definitely enjoyable!

Really think about whether you have the appropriate background to dive into the material of your particular tutorial. I thought the class would be much slower-paced than it actually was, and there were not great resources to help aid in my understanding of the material. I love mathematics, but this was unfortunately a very poor academic experience for me.
Every math student should take at least one tutorial as an undergraduate. They are fabulous.
Group Cohomology is an amazing mix of algebra and topology with some extraordinary applications. Though it is rather hard to learn heavy homological algebra from a lecture. Meng is wonderful!

Campbell was an amazing teacher. He truly cared about the students and made sure we were able to understand the material. It was clear that he was a little frustrated that the overall caliber of the students in the class was not quite high enough and hence couldn't go a bit faster. Regardless, the lectures were excellent, psets were well constructed, and Campbell was an awesome. I can not think of a better way to have learned category theory!
Tutorials are awesome--learn great material at low stress!

I took 'Group Cohomology' with Meng Guo. The material isn't super hard if you are familiar with some homological algebra or maybe algebraic topology. But I didn't have enough motivation for defining or computing group cohomologies, and this made the whole theory look a bit artificial. The lectures were generally good, and the best thing about a tutorial is that the atmosphere was a lot more relaxed than other lectures. I recommend every math concentrator to take at least one tutorial.

Justin Campbell is a great lecturer and category theory is a very interesting subject! The course is super chill and Justin is very helpful (he posts pset solutions and gives comments). The final paper was actually enjoyable to write as well.
